It was the blessed morn of Whitsuntide,</br>And Carduel echoed to the festive call,</br>As his shrill task the clear-voiced herald plied,</br>And shriller trumpet shook the castle wall.

Ye whom the world has wrong'd, whom men despise,</br>Who sadly wander through this vale of tears,</br>And lift in silent dread your wistful eyes</br>O'er the bleak wilderness of future years,</br>Where from the storm no sheltering bourn appears;</br>Whom genius, moody guide, has led astray,</br>And pride has mock'd, and want with chilling fears,</br>Quench'd of each youthful hope the timid ray;</br>Yet envy not the great, yet envy not the gay!

Say, can the silken bed refreshment bring,</br>When from the restless spirit sleep retires?</br>Or, the sharp fever of the serpent's sting,</br>Pains it less shrewdly for his burnish'd spires?</br>Oh, worthless is the bliss the world admires,</br>And helpless whom the vulgar mightiest deem;</br>Tasteless fruition, impotent desires,</br>Pomp, pleasure, pride, how valueless ye seem</br>When the poor soul awakes, and finds its life a dream!

And those, if such may ponder o'er my song,</br>Whose light heart bounds to pleasure's minstrelsy;</br>To whom the faery realms of love belong;</br>And the gay motes of young prosperity,</br>Dance in thy sunshine and obscure thine eye;</br>Suspect of earthly good the gilded snare,</br>When sorrow wreathes her brow with revelry,</br>And friendship's hollow smiles thy wreck prepare!</br>Alas!  that demon forms should boast a mask so fair!

See'st thou yon flutterer in the summer sky,</br>Wild as thy glance, and graceful as thy form?</br>Yet, lady, know, yon beauteous butterfly</br>Is parent of the loathsome canker-worm,</br>Whose restless tooth, worse than December's storm,</br>Shall mar thy woodbine bower with greedy rage.—</br>Fair was her face as thine, her heart as warm,</br>Whose antique story marks my simple page;</br>Yet luckless youth was hers, and sorrowful old age!

'Twas merry in the streets of Carduel,</br>When Pentecost renew'd her festive call,</br>And the loud trumpet's clang and louder bell</br>The moss-grown abbey shook and banner'd wall;</br>And still, from bower to mass, from mass to hall,</br>A sea of heads throughout the city flowed;</br>And, robed in fur, in purple, and in pall,</br>Of knights and dames the gaudy pageant yode,</br>And conquering Arthur last, and young Ganora rode.

Still as they pass'd, from many a scaffold high,</br>And window-lattice scatter'd roses flew,</br>And maidens, leaning from the balcony,</br>Bent their white necks the stranger bride to view,</br>Whom that same morn, or ere the sparkling dew</br>Had from his city's herb-strewn pavement fled,</br>A village maid, who rank nor splendour knew,</br>To Mary's aisle the conqueror's hand had led,</br>To deck her monarch's throne, to bless her monarch's bed.

Who then was joyful but the Logrian king?</br>Not that his hand a five-fold sceptre bore;</br>Not that the Scandian raven's robber wing</br>Stoop'd to his dragon banner, and the shore</br>Of peopled Gallia, and where ocean hoar</br>Girds with his silver ring the island green</br>Of saints and heroes; not that paynim gore</br>Clung to his blade, and, first in danger seen,</br>In many a forward fight his golden shield had been.

Nor warrior fame it was, nor kingly state</br>That swell'd his heart, though in that thoughtful eye</br>And brow that might not, even in mirth, abate</br>Its regal care and wonted majesty,</br>Unlike to love, a something seem'd to lie;</br>Yet love's ascendant planet rul'd the hour.</br>And as he gaz'd with lover's ecstacy,</br>And blended pride upon that beauteous flower,</br>Could fame, could empire vie with such a paramour?

For many a melting eye of deepest blue,</br>And many a form of goodliest mould were there,</br>And ivory necks and lips of coral hue,</br>And many an auburn braid of glossy hair.</br>But ill might all those gorgeous dames compare</br>With her in flowers and bridal white array'd;</br>Was none so stately form nor face so fair</br>As hers, whose eyes, as mournful or afraid,</br>Were big with heavy tears, the trembling village maid.

Yet whoso list her dark and lucid eye,</br>And the pure witness of her cheek to read,</br>Might written mark in nature's registry,</br>That this fair rustic was not such indeed,</br>But high-born offspring of some ancient seed.</br>And, sooth, she was the heir of Carmelide,</br>And old Ladugan's blood, whose daring deed</br>With rebel gore Lancastrian meadows dyed,</br>Or ere that Uther's son his mightier aid supplied.

But, when the murderous Ryence' archer band</br>With broad destruction swept the Ribble side,</br>Ladugan forth from that devoted land</br>His daughter sent, a smiling babe, to bide</br>Where Derwent's lonely mirror dark and wide</br>Reflects the dappled heaven and purple steep,</br>Unhonour'd there, unown'd and undescried,</br>Till fate compell'd her from her tended sheep,</br>In Arthur's kingly bower to wear a crown and weep.

There are who teach such crystal drops express</br>(So near is each extreme of joy or woe)</br>Alike, the burst of painful happiness,</br>And the still smart of misery's inward throe.</br>From man's perturbed soul alike they flow,</br>Where bitter doubt and recollected sorrow</br>Blend with the cup of bliss, and none can know</br>From human grief how short a space to borrow,</br>Or how the fairest eve may bring the darkest morrow.

Say, fared it thus with young Ganora's heart?</br>Did hope, did Hymen call the rapturous tear?</br>Or mourn'd perchance the village maid to part</br>From all the humble joys her heart held dear?</br>And, turning from that kingly front severe,</br>Roam'd her sad memory o'er each milder grace</br>Of him her earliest love, the forestere?</br>Ah lost for ever now!  yet sweet to trace</br>The silver studded horn, green garb, and beardless face.

The chanted anthem's heaven-ascending sound</br>Her spirit mov'd not with its sacred swell;</br>And, all in vain, for twenty steeples round</br>Crash'd with sonorous din the festive bell;</br>Upon her tranced ear in vain it fell!</br>As little mark'd she, that the monarch's tongue</br>Would oft of love in courtly whisper tell;</br>While from the castle bridge a minstrel throng,</br>To many a gilded harp attun'd the nuptial song.

"Ah see," 'twas thus began the lovely lay,</br>"The warrior-god hath laid his armour by,</br>And doft his deadly sword, awhile to play</br>In the dark radiance of Dione's eye;</br>Snared in her raven locks behold him lie,</br>And on her lap his dreadful head reclined;</br>May every knight such silken fetters try,</br>Such mutual bands may every lady bind!</br>How blest the soldier's life if love were always kind!

"Oh Goddess of the soul-entrancing zone,</br>Look down and mark a fairer Venus here,</br>Call'd from her hamlet to an empire's throne,</br>As meet of womankind the crown to wear,</br>And of a nobler Mars the consort dear!</br>Oh fairest, mildest, best, by heaven design'd</br>With soothing smiles his kingly toil to cheer,</br>Still may thy dulcet chain the conqueror bind.</br>Sure earth itself were heaven if love were always kind!"

So sang they till the gaudy train had past</br>The sullen entrance of that ancient tower,</br>Which o'er the trembling wave its shadow cast,</br>Grim monument of Rome's departed power.</br>That same, in Albion's tributary hour,</br>The Latian lords of earth had edified,</br>Which all unharm'd in many a martial stour,</br>Might endless as the steadfast hills abide,</br>Or as the eternal stream that crept its base beside.

And Arthur here had fix'd his kingly see,</br>And hither had he borne his destin'd bride,</br>Amid those civil storms secure to be</br>That rock'd the troublous land on every side.</br>For not the fell balista, bristling wide</br>With barbed death, or whirling rocks afar,</br>Nor aught by that Trinacrian artist tried,</br>To save his leagured town such strength could mar.</br>How easy then to mock the barbarous Saxon war.

Austere and stern, a warrior front it wore,</br>The long dim entrance to that palace pile,</br>And crisped moss, and lichen ever hoar,</br>Trail'd their moist tresses in the portal aisle.</br>But, past the gate, like some rude veteran's smile</br>Kindly, through dark, a milder grace it show'd;</br>And music shook the courts, and all the while</br>Fair stripling youths along the steepy road,</br>Fresh flowers before their feet and myrtle branches strew'd.

By them they pass, and now the giant hall</br>Bids to the train its oaken valves unfold,</br>From whose high rafter'd roof and arched wall,</br>Five hundred pennons, prize of war, unroll'd,</br>In various silk display'd and waving gold,</br>The armories of many a conquer'd knight;</br>And some of Arthur's sword the fortune told,</br>Of Gawain some, but most were redde aright,</br>"These Lancelot du Lake achieved in open fight."

Here might I sing (what many a bard has sung)</br>Each gorgeous usage of that kingly hall;</br>How harp, and voice, and clashing goblet rung,</br>Of page and herald, bard and seneschall.</br>But antique times were rude and homely all;</br>And ill might Arthur's nuptial banquet vie,</br>With theirs who nature's kindly fruits forestall,</br>And brave the seas for frantic gluttony,</br>And every various bane of every clime supply,

Nor car'd the king, a soldier tried and true,</br>For such vain pampering of impure delight.</br>His toys, his gauds, were all of manlier hue,</br>Swift steeds, keen dogs, sharp swords, and armour bright;</br>Yet wanted nought that well became a knight</br>Of seemly pomp; the floor with rushes green,</br>And smooth bright board with plenteous viands dight,</br>That scant the load might bear, though well be seen</br>With ribs and rafters strong, and ponderous oak between.

And shame it were to pass the warrior state</br>Of those, the favour'd few, whose table round,</br>Fast by their sovereign and his beauteous mate,</br>Apart from all the subject train, was crowned,</br>Whose manly locks with laurel wreaths were bound,</br>And ermine wrapt their limbs; yet on the wall</br>Their helms, and spears, and painted shields were found,</br>And mails, and gilded greaves, at danger's call,</br>Aye prompt for needful use whatever chance might fall.

And bounded high the monarch's heart of pride,</br>Who gazed exulting on that noble crew;</br>And leaning to his silent spouse, he cried,</br>"Seest thou, Ganore, thy band of liegemen true?</br>Lo, these are they whose fame the liquid blue</br>Of upper air transcends; nor lives there one</br>Of all who gaze on Phoebus' golden hue,</br>From earth's cold circle to the burning zone,</br>To whom of Arthur's knights the toil remains unknown.

"Yes, mark him well, the chief whose auburn hair</br>So crisply curls above his hazel eye,</br>And parted leaves the manly forehead bare.</br>That same is Gawain, flower of courtesy;</br>Yet few with him in listed field may vie.</br>Gahriet the next, in blood the next and might;</br>And Carados whose lady's loyalty</br>The mantle gain'd and horn of silver bright;</br>And stout Sir Kay, stout heart, but not so strong in fight.

"But he, the best of all and bravest peer</br>That drinks this hour the crystal air of day;</br>The most renowned and to me most dear,</br>As ill befalls, is journey'd far away,</br>A strange and stern adventure to essay,</br>Whom Heaven defend, and to his friend's embrace</br>Again resistless Lancelot convey!"</br>So spake the king, and more his words to grace,</br>An unsuspected tear stole down his manly face.

To whom with faltering voice Ganora spake,</br>"Oh happy knights of such a king," she said,</br>"And happy king for whose revered sake</br>So valiant knights unsheathe the deadly blade!</br>And worthless I, an untaught village maid,</br>In Arthur's court to fill the envied throne,</br>Who meeter far in russet weeds array'd,</br>Had fed my flock on Skiddaw's summit lone,</br>Unknowing of mankind and by mankind unknown."

The monarch smiled, a proud protecting smile,</br>That spoke her lovelier for her lowliness;</br>And, bending from his loftier seat the while,</br>Hung o'er her heaving form, yet ill could guess</br>What terror strove within, what deep distress</br>Rose in her painful throat, while struggling there,</br>A stronger awe the sob would fain repress;</br>Nor other cause he sought than maiden fear</br>To chill the shrinking hand, to call the trickling tear.

"Mine own Ganore!"  he said, "my gentle maid!</br>Oh deem not of thyself unworthily;</br>By charms like thine a king were well repaid,</br>Who yielded up for love his royalty.</br>And heroes old, and they that rule the sky,</br>Have sought in lowly cot, as fables tell,</br>A purer love than gems or gold can buy,</br>And beauty oftener found in mountain cell,</br>Than with the lofty dames in regal court who dwell.

"Go, ask the noblest of my knightly power,</br>Ask of Sir Lancelot, what secret pain</br>So oft hath drawn him forth at twilight hour,</br>To woods and wilds, his absent love to plain,</br>Whom many a courtly fair hath sought in vain?</br>Oh, he will tell thee that the greenwood tree</br>Recalls the hour of happier youth again,</br>When blithe he wont to range the forest free,</br>With her, his earliest choice, the maid of low degree."

He ceased, to whom the maiden nought replied,</br>But in the patience of her misery</br>Possess'd her secret soul, and inly sigh'd.</br>"Why ponder thus on what no more may be?</br>Why think on him who never thinks on thee?</br>For now seven autumns have with changing hue</br>Embrown'd the verdure of our trysting tree,</br>Since that shrill horn the wonted signal blew,</br>Or that swift foot was heard brushing the twilight dew.

"Then rouse thee yet thy silent griefs to bear,</br>And rein the troublous thoughts so far that rove:</br>Faithless or dead, he little needs thy care;</br>And ill such thoughts a wedded wife behove;</br>Then turn to him who claims thy plighted love;</br>Nor weeping thus, thine inward shame confess,</br>Whom knightly worth nor regal state may move;</br>Nor he whom Albion's sister islands bless,</br>Can tame thy stubborn grief and minion frowardness!"

So sadly past the festal eve away,</br>While at each courteous word her bosom bled,</br>And every glance her heart could ill repay,</br>Through the chill conscience like a dagger sped.</br>Yet still with secret prayer her soul she fed,</br>And burst with holier thoughts each inward snare,</br>Which in that wither'd heart, where hope was dead,</br>Yet hopeless passion wove, and darkest there,</br>The dreadful whisper crept of comfortless despair.

And softer seem'd her silent grief to flow,</br>And sweeter far her unrestrained tear,</br>While soft and sweet, a tale of tender woe</br>Iola wove, the bard, whose harp to hear</br>Even the rude warder, leaning on his spear,</br>Prest to the further door; and squire, and knight,</br>And lingering pages on those accents dear,</br>Paus'd round the unserved board; and ladies bright,</br>Breathless, with lips unclos'd, drank in the wild delight.

A strange and melancholy tale it was,</br>"Of one who, for a tyrant uncle's right,</br>Lay bleeding, breathless, on the crimson grass,</br>All vainly victor in th' unequal fight;</br>And who is she whose hands of lily white,</br>Too beauteous leech!  his festering hurt would bind?</br>Ah, fly thee, princess, from the Cornish knight,</br>Who, now preserv'd, a sorer fate must find,</br>By guilt, and late remorse, and hopeless passion pin'd.

"Yet pleasant was the dawn of early love,</br>And sweet the faery bowl of magic power!</br>But following mists the early heat reprove,</br>And April frosts abash the timid flower.</br>Behold him now at midnight's harmful hour,</br>His pale cheek pillow'd on his trembling knees,</br>Whose frantic brain rejects the shelt'ring bower,</br>Whose parched bosom woos the autumnal breeze,</br>And whose poor broken heart sighs with the sighing trees.

"Ah, sweet it seem'd when, through the livelong day,</br>'Mid tall Ierne's forest dark and wide,</br>In hunter garb he took his tireless way,</br>Love in his breast and Yseult at his side!</br>Gone are those days!  Oh Yseult, oft he cried,</br>Relentless Yseult, beauteous enemy!</br>May happier fate thy gentle life betide,</br>Nor ever may'st thou waste a tear on me,</br>Nor guess the nameless tomb of him who pined for thee!

"And Lancelot!  (for, Lordings, well ye know</br>How Tristan aye to Lancelot was dear)</br>Sir Lancelot!  he sung, of all below</br>The best, the bravest, and the worthiest peer!</br>To thee my helm I leave, and shield and spear,</br>That not from harm their wretched lord might save.</br>Yet, noblest friend, my last petition hear,</br>By thine own secret love a boon I crave,</br>Defend mine Yseult's fame when I am laid in grave."

Here ceas'd the harp; but o'er its trembling chord</br>In silent grief the minstrel's sorrow fell,</br>And silence hush'd the throng where all deplor'd</br>The recent woes of knight who lov'd so well,</br>And most had known the heir of Lionelle;</br>And sweet it seem'd for others' woe to weep</br>To her whose secret anguish none could tell;</br>Yet nigh such strain could lull her pangs to sleep;</br>And now the star of eve beam'd o'er the twilight deep.

When, in that sober light and sadness still,</br>Arose a madd'ning hubbub hoarse and rude,</br>Like hunters on the brow of dewy hill,</br>And panting deer by nearer hounds pursued:</br>And a cold shudder thrill'd the multitude,</br>As, at the breath of that mysterious horn,</br>Each with inquiring gaze his neighbour view'd,</br>For never peal on woodland echoes borne,</br>So ghastly and so shrill awoke the spangled morn.

At once the steely bars in twain were rent;</br>At once the oaken valves asunder flew;</br>And warrior breasts, in iron corslets pent,</br>Their tighten'd breath with painful effort drew;</br>For louder, louder far the tumult grew,</br>That earth's firm planet quaked at the din,</br>And the thick air assumed a browner hue,</br>Such as on Nilus' bank hath whilom bin,</br>When Amram's mighty son rebuked the tyrant's sin.

And through the portal arch that open'd wide</br>(How came she or from whence no thought could tell)</br>The wedding-guests with fearful wonder eyed,</br>A hind of loveliest mould, whose snowy fell</br>Was dyed, alas!  with dolorous vermeill.</br>For down her ruffled flank the current red,</br>From many a wound issued in fatal well,</br>As staggering faint with feeble haste she sped,</br>And on Ganora's lap reclin'd her piteous head.

With claws of molten brass, and eyes of flame,</br>A grisly troop of hell-hounds thronging near,</br>And on her foamy steed a damsel came,</br>A damsel fair to see, whose maiden cheer</br>But ill beseem'd the ruthless hunting spear;</br>Whose golden locks in silken net were twin'd,</br>And pure as heaving snow her bosom dear;</br>Yet ceased she not that dreadful horn to wind,</br>And strain'd a quivering dart for fatal use design'd.

Reckless of loathed life, and free from stain</br>Of deep transgression, could Ganora fear!</br>Forlorn herself, she felt for others' pain,</br>And cast her sheltering robe around the deer.</br>To whom that magic maid with brow severe</br>And glaring eye, "Oh, doom'd to lasting woe,</br>Waste not, unhappy queen, thy pity here,</br>Nor bid my righteous rage its prey forego,</br>Who keener pangs thyself, Ganora, soon shalt know!

"Poor wither'd heart, that hid'st from human eye</br>The bitter secret of thine inward wound,</br>Go, doff the cumbrous garb of royalty,</br>And seek betimes the cloister's sacred bound!</br>Ah, warn'd in vain!  I hear the clarion sound;</br>Rings to the charger's tread the shadowy glen;</br>For thee, for thee, the guarded list is crown'd;</br>For thee dark treason quits her snaky den;</br>The battle's roar resounds for thee, and groans of mangled men!

"Heap high the wood, and bid the flames aspire!</br>Bind her long tresses to th' accursed tree!</br>A queen, a queen, must feed the funeral fire!</br>Ah, hope not thou, though love shall set thee free,</br>With that restored love in peace to be.</br>And shall my country bend her awful head</br>To lick the bitter dust of slavery?</br>Illustrious isle!  is all thy glory fled?</br>How soon thy knightly boast is number'd with the dead!

"Yet art thou safe, and Arthur's throne may stand."</br>(Down from the lofty saddle, bending low,</br>The dart she proffer'd to Ganora's hand;)</br>"Nay, shrink not, maiden, from the needful blow,</br>Nor spare, in yonder hind, thy fiercest foe,</br>Whose secret hate from forth her dark recess,</br>Besets thy guiltless life with snares of woe.</br>Take, take the steel!  thy wrongs and mine redress!</br>Mercy were impious here! — be strong, be merciless!"

Giddy and faint, unknowing where she was,</br>Or if, indeed, were sooth that ghastly view,</br>Pale as some wintry lake, whose frozen glass</br>Steals from the snow-clad heaven a paler hue,</br>Ganora sate; but still, to pity true,</br>Her milk-white arms around the quarry spread,</br>Then rais'd to Heaven her eyes of mildest blue,</br>And to her cheek return'd a dawning red,</br>As, with collected soul, she bow'd herself and said:—

"And I can suffer!  let the storm descend;</br>Let on this helpless head the thunder break;</br>Yet, exercis'd in grief, yet, God to friend,</br>I can endure the worst for mercy's sake!</br>No, wretched suppliant!"  (to the hind she spake</br>That lick'd her hand, and with large tearful eye</br>Dwelt on her gentle face:) "thy fears forsake!</br>Be thou my friend, I doom thee not to die,</br>And thy mute love shall cheer my joyless royalty."

"Have then thy wish!"  the spectre damsel cried,</br>And call'd her dogs, and wheel'd her courser round,</br>And with the javelin smote his quivering side;</br>When, swifter than the rocket's fiery bound,</br>Aloft they sprang, huntress, and horse, and hound,</br>And, dimly mixing with the horizon grey,</br>Fled like a winged dream, yet traces found</br>Of gore and talons told their recent way;</br>And still before the queen that wounded quarry lay.

How fares the knightly court of Carduel?</br>How fare the wedding guests and warrior throng,</br>Where all conspired the nuptial mirth to swell,</br>The dance, the feast, the laugh, the wine, the song?</br>Oh they are silent all!  the nimble tongue</br>Of him, whose craft, by motley kirtle known,</br>Had graver wits with seeming folly stung;</br>The vaunting soldier and the simpering crone,</br>And breath'd in beauty's ear the sighs of softest tone.

As one who, stretch'd upon a battle-field,</br>Looks to the foeman's hand who laid him low,</br>And, with faint effort, rears his broken shield,</br>And dreads, where needeth none, a second blow.—</br>Or, likest him who, where the surges' flow</br>Bares the bleak surface of some wave-beat steep,</br>A shipwreck'd man, expects in breathless woe,</br>Till the returning wave, with giant sweep,</br>Unlock his desperate hold, and whelm him in the deep.

So blended fears, the future and the past,</br>The past yet seen by terror's glazed eye,</br>That, tearless still and wild, those phantoms traced,</br>Peopling the twilight's dismal vacancy</br>With fancied shapes, and shades of fiendish dye;</br>The future wildest, darkest, unexprest,</br>Danger untry'd, unfancy'd agony,</br>In the mute language of dismay confest,</br>Thrill'd in the bristling hair, throbb'd in th' expanded breast.

Sternly the monarch rose, and o'er his brow</br>A horrent pang of dark anxiety</br>Shot like the stormy shadow, scudding low</br>Along the surface of the purple sea.</br>A smile succeeded.  Not to mine, or me,</br>Be that portentous smile of hate and scorn,</br>Which each strong furrow, stronger made to be,</br>By toil, and care, and ruthless passion worn,</br>And recollected guilt of youth's tempestuous morn!

"Sister!"  he spake, (half-utter'd, half-represt,</br>From his shut teeth the sullen accents stole;)</br>"And deem'st thou, sister, that thine arts unblest</br>Can tame the settled bent of Arthur's soul?</br>No; let the stars their fiery circles roll;</br>Let dreams of woe disturb the prophet's breast:</br>Can these, or those, the warrior's will controul?</br>'Tis chance, 'tis errour all! — Oh, trusted best!</br>Be thou mine omen, sword!  I reck not of the rest!"

The wedded pair are to their chamber gone,</br>While minstrel sounds of breath, and beat, and string</br>Pour on the dewy breeze their blended tone;</br>And wreathed maidens, link'd in jocund ring,</br>"Hymen" around them, "Io Hymen" sing.</br>So, trampling roses in their path, they sped,</br>The veiled bride and the triumphant king,</br>A festal glare while hundred torches shed,</br>Tinging the cheek of night with all unwonted red.
